episodes.original_body:
Case: Michael-Crader-MVA-5-19-2023
Client: Michael Crader

Ms Crader called me to ensure the email from Coleen was for our office regarding his case - (so much fraud she wanted to check that the request was from our office) . Ms Crader said his healthcare (VA) only has his SS# and his picture on it. They are awaiting approval from VA that he can go to UK for his back injury. I explained to Ms Crader that Coleen is his case manager - and that any documents go directly to his file. #cc
episodes.natural_language:
Initial client contact on May 19, 2023 with Michael Crader regarding motor vehicle accident. Ms Crader called to verify that the email from Coleen was for our office regarding his case, expressing concerns about fraud and wanting to confirm the request originated from our office. She stated that his VA health care card currently contains only his Social Security number and a photo.

They are awaiting VA approval for him to travel to the United Kingdom for his back injury. I explained that Coleen is his case manager and that any documents should be sent directly to his file. The note ends with '#cc'.
episodes.author: Faye Gaither

In the Michael-Crader-MVA-5-19-2023 case, the client is Michael Crader and the matter involves communications with the Whaley Law Firm regarding medical bills after a motor vehicle accident.

On September 13, 2023, Coleen Thea Ferry Madayag of the Whaley Law Firm sent an email to Mr. Crader (michaelcrader67@gmail.com). In that message, she introduced herself as Coleen from the Whaley Law Firm and requested that Crader send copies of the bills he had received. The exact wording included: “Hi Mr./Mrs. Crader, This is Coleen from the Whaley Law Firm. You can send here the copy of the bills you received. Thank you.” The message was signed with Coleen Madayag and included her contact information: Whaley Law Firm, Ph: (502)450-9495, Fax: (502)364-9363, coleen@whaleylawfirm.com.

The following day, September 14, 2023, Crader responded to Coleen’s request. At approximately 6:59 AM (the timestamp shows as 6:59?AM), Crader wrote that he was sending “the uk bill” and that he was still waiting on “life flight.” He sent the message from his iPad.

Later that same day, at 8:04 AM Eastern Time, Coleen replied: “Received. This is noted. Thank you.” Her response confirms receipt of Crader’s message and acknowledges it.

Case: Michael-Crader-MVA-5-19-2023
Client: Michael Crader

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ Called client, spoke with Mrs. Crader, she stated that Air Methods is the one who airlifted the client, and the phone number for them is 855-896-9067. Called Air Methods at 855-896-9067, spoke with a staff, she confirmed that they are the one who responded and airlifted Mr. Crader last May 19, 2023. She provided a fax number to request medical records and bills. The fax number is 402-952-2413. Saved information on file.

And as per Mrs. Crader, they did not take any photos of the injuries and accident scene. But she mentioned that the police may have taken photos.

And regarding lost wages, she stated that they own a farm and they both do all the stuff in the farm like water lining, but since Mr. Crader had injuries, they have to hire others to do the work. 
__Person Making Contact:__ Coleen
__Date & Time__: September 14 2023
episodes.natural_language:
Initial client contact on September 14, 2023 with Coleen regarding motor vehicle accident involving Michael Crader on May 19, 2023.

Mrs. Crader stated that Air Methods is the air ambulance provider who airlifted Mr. Crader. She provided Air Methods’ phone number as 855-896-9067. I called Air Methods at that number and spoke with a staff member who confirmed that they responded to the incident and airlifted Mr. Crader on May 19, 2023. She also provided a fax number to request medical records and bills: 402-952-2413. This information has been saved on file. Mrs. Crader also noted that they did not take any photos of the injuries or the accident scene, but she mentioned that the police may have taken photos. Regarding lost wages, she stated that they own a farm and both perform all the farm work, including water lining, but since Mr. Crader was injured, they have had to hire others to do the work.
episodes.author: Filevine Integration

episodes.original_body:
Case: Michael-Crader-MVA-5-19-2023
Client: Michael Crader

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ From: Michael Crader
Sent: Friday, October 6, 2023 1:43 PM
To: justin@whaleylawfirm.com
Subject: Loss of wages letter

With the accident that occurred on May 19,2023 it caused loss of wages as well as additional loss that is hard to measure. We had to hire out the input of waterline because with Mike?s injury to his back he was unable to put the waterline in himself. The cost of the waterline was $10,800. Mikes was hoping that his back injury would be healed so we could put the fence in but as of today, October 6, 2023 he is still hurting. With the fence unable to be constructed we had to purchase additional hay to feed our cattle. The field that was unable to be fenced produces approximately 500 rolls worth of feed for cattle. With the drought we only could secure 463 bales of hay at $55 a bale totaling $25,465 to offset the cattle unable to graze on the unfenced field due to the injury caused by the accident on May 19,2023. This does not take into account all the additional projects and maintenance that need to be done on the farm that we are unable to do due to Mike?s injury. We are self-employed farmers on top of the loss of wages, the amount of stress and mental anguish this has caused is staggering.
Sincerely
Mary Jane & Michael Crader 
__Person Making Contact:__ Justin
__Date & Time__: October 06 2023
episodes.natural_language:
Initial client contact on October 6, 2023, regarding the motor vehicle accident that occurred on May 19, 2023. The message was sent by Michael Crader to Justin at justin@whaleylawfirm.com on Friday, October 6, 2023, at 1:43 PM, with the subject “Loss of wages letter.”

Michael Crader explains that the May 19, 2023 accident caused loss of wages as well as additional losses that are difficult to measure. They had to hire out the installation of the waterline because, due to Mike’s back injury, he was unable to do it himself; the cost of the waterline was $10,800. Mike had hoped that his back injury would heal so they could install the fence, but as of October 6, 2023 he is still hurting. With the fence unable to be constructed, they had to purchase additional hay to feed their cattle. The unfenced field produces approximately 500 rolls’ worth of feed for cattle. Because of the drought, they were able to secure only 463 bales of hay at $55 per bale, totaling $25,465, to offset the cattle unable to graze on the unfenced field due to the May 19, 2023 accident. This does not account for all the other farm projects and maintenance they are unable to undertake due to Mike’s injury. They are self-employed farmers, and in addition to the loss of wages, the stress and mental anguish this has caused is staggering.

Sincerely, Mary Jane & Michael Crader. The person making contact is Justin. Date & Time: October 06, 2023.

The VA has received your request for billing records regarding M. Crader
relating to treatment provided by or paid for by the Lexington VA
Healthcare System. Please note the request can take up to 60 days to
process.

Your request was entered on 1/8/2024. If you have not received a response
by 3/8/2024, please contact the Lexington VA Healthcare System Facilty
Revenue office at:

(859) 281-3828
vhalexcpacmscpacfacilityrevenuelexington@va.gov

When following up on the request, please reference:

LAWS# 596-C-20240108-14823

Medical records must be requested separately from the Lexington VA
Healthcare System: https://www.va.gov/lexington-health-care/

Information on how to submit a new VA billing request, requesting bills for
family members of veterans and other helpful information can be found here:
https://www.va.gov/OGC/Collections.asp

Please be advised that failure to respond with information necessary for VA
to identify its claim does not absolve you of your duty to VA. Be advised
that all Veterans and Veterans' beneficiaries, or those individuals acting
on their behalf, have an affirmative duty to notify VA of care provided or
paid for in connection with a personal injury or workers compensation case.
88 Fed. Reg. 8344. As such, prior to distributing any proceeds from a
settlement or judgment, it is your responsibility to confer with the
Veteran to ensure that the Veteran has not received related care provided
or paid for by VA (including pending or potential claims for VA payment).

======================================================================================================================

This email was sent from an account for sending messages only. Please do
not reply to this email as we will not receive your response. To follow up
on the request, please see the contact information provided in the email
above. More information can be found here:
https://www.va.gov/OGC/Collections.asp

Client: Michael Crader

On January 9, 2024, a forwarded email thread was received regarding VA Bill Request Confirmation for LAWS# 596-C-20240108-14823 in relation to Michael Crader. The forward came from Jessica Bottorff and was addressed to MichaelCraderMVAZ3893535@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com, with the subject line “FW: VA Bill Request Confirmation - LAWS# 596-C-20240108-14823.” The forwarded content includes a message from Justin Chumbley of Whaley Law Firm, who provided Whaley Law Firm’s contact information: Ph: (502) 583-4022 and Fax: (502) 364-9363.

The original message in the chain is from OGC VA Bills (DO NOT Reply – Not Monitored), sent Monday, January 8, 2024 at 2:52 PM, to justin@whaleylawfirm.com. It confirms that the VA has received a request for billing records regarding M. Crader related to treatment provided by or paid for by the Lexington VA Healthcare System, and notes that the processing time can be up to 60 days. The VA states that the request was entered on 1/8/2024, and provides guidance for follow-up if no response is received by 3/8/2024, including contact details for the Lexington VA Healthcare System Facility Revenue Office: (859) 281-3828 and vhalexcpacmscpacfacilityrevenuelexington@va.gov. When following up, responders are instructed to reference LAWS# 596-C-20240108-14823.

The VA also notes that medical records must be requested separately from the Lexington VA Healthcare System and provides the link https://www.va.gov/lexington-health-care/. Additional information on submitting a new VA billing request, requesting bills for family members of veterans, and other relevant information can be found at https://www.va.gov/OGC/Collections.asp. The VA reminds recipients that failure to respond with information necessary for VA to identify its claim does not absolve the recipient of duties to VA. All Veterans and Veterans’ beneficiaries, or those acting on their behalf, have an affirmative duty to notify VA of care provided or paid for in connection with a personal injury or workers’ compensation case (88 Fed. Reg. 8344). Consequently, prior to distributing any proceeds from a settlement or judgment, the recipient must confer with the Veteran to ensure the Veteran has not received related care provided or paid for by VA (including pending or potential VA payment claims).

The email further notes that this message was sent from an account used only for sending messages and that replies are not monitored. For follow-up, contact information provided in the email should be used, and more information can be found here: https://www.va.gov/OGC/Collections.asp.

Case: Michael-Crader-MVA-5-19-2023
Client: Michael Crader

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ Recvd Message from FG - Client would like an update - Called Client - Wife answered & remained on the line - Verified Client Present - Client is frustrated at how long this is taking - Advised we are still attempting service on Def - Client states that he sees her everyday at the same house - Advised Client that per the Initial Service Results she no longer lives there - We ran a search and confirmed Def has new address - Client does not believe Def has moved - Discussed Service process & all possible outcomes - Reassured Client that Liability was accepted, however, the passengers in the At Fault Vehicle also have a right to make a claim and their time frame to do is 2 years from the Date of Incident - While we hope Litigation will help speed up the process, we can not force the BI to disregard the SOL - Client's Wife expressed understanding and appreciate the update & explanation. 
__Person Making Contact:__ Sarena
__Date & Time__: June 26 2024
episodes.natural_language:
Initial client contact on June 26, 2024, with Sarena regarding Michael Crader's motor vehicle accident (MVA) case dated May 19, 2023. We received a message from FG indicating that the client would like an update. I called the client; his wife answered and remained on the line, and I verified that the client was present.

The client expressed frustration at how long this is taking. I advised that we are still attempting service on the defendant. The client stated that he sees her everyday at the same house, but I advised him that per the Initial Service Results she no longer lives there. We ran a search and confirmed the defendant has a new address, though the client does not believe the defendant has moved. We discussed the service process and all possible outcomes. I reassured the client that liability had been accepted; however, the passengers in the at-fault vehicle also have a right to make a claim, and their time frame to do so is two years from the date of the incident. While we hope litigation will help speed up the process, we cannot force BI to disregard the SOL. The client's wife expressed understanding and appreciated the update and explanation.

Case: Michael-Crader-MVA-5-19-2023
Client: Michael Crader

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ Recvd Client VM - BK completed Check Svc Task Prior to POS - Reviewed Case in CourtNet - No POS uploaded - Response Filed On 07/19/2024 was noted but Doc not uploaded - Called Clerk - Clerk emailed Handwritten Answer to Complaint - Reviewed - Called Client - Explained Def Combs has been served but Sheriff did not send in POS to Court - Advised Def Combs filed Handwritten Answer - Advised while Liability is not our issue at the moment, Def Combs did admit to improper passing - Advised we will send Handwritten Answer to BI for proper counsel to be appointed - Explained to Client that our current issue is her mother's injuries & her mother having a right to a portion of the Policy Limits - Client states Mother was driving not Def Combs - Advised neither here nor there at the moment - Mother is entitled to portion of BI Policy due to injuries & that is our hold up - Mother needs to make claim or waive right to claim - Advised Client that hopefully once proper DC appointed DC can address w/Def & see if mother is going to make claim or not - Client expressed understanding 
__Person Making Contact:__ Sarena
__Date & Time__: July 31 2024
episodes.natural_language:
Initial client contact on July 31, 2024, with Michael Crader regarding the Michael-Crader-MVA-5-19-2023 case. The client’s voicemail was received. BK completed Check Svc Task Prior to POS, and I reviewed the case in CourtNet. No POS has been uploaded. The response filed on 07/19/2024 was noted, but the document had not been uploaded. I called the Clerk, who emailed a handwritten Answer to the Complaint, which I reviewed, and then I spoke with the client.

I explained that Defendants Combs have been served, but the Sheriff did not send in POS to the Court. I advised that Def Combs filed a handwritten Answer and noted that, while liability is not our current issue, Def Combs did admit to improper passing. I advised that we will send the handwritten Answer to BI for proper counsel to be appointed. I explained to the client that our present issue concerns her mother’s injuries and her mother’s right to a portion of the Policy Limits. The client stated that the mother was driving, not Def Combs, but I noted that this distinction is not central at the moment. The mother’s entitlement to a portion of the BI Policy due to injuries is our hold up, and the mother needs to make a claim or waive the right to claim. I advised the client that hopefully once proper DC is appointed, DC can address the situation with Def and determine whether the mother will make a claim. The client expressed understanding.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Michael-Crader-MVA-5-19-2023. Client: Michael Crader. This note documents the communications surrounding Claim 04863358, Michael Crader v. Megan Combs.

On July 31, 2024, Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager at The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email to Kentucky Farm Bureau agent Hailey Conley (subject: “Claim: 04863358 Michael Crader v Megan Combs”). In that message, she thanked Hailey for the assistance and advised that copies of the documents referenced in a voicemail were attached. The message states that the Complaint filed against Mrs. Combs in the Morgan County Circuit Court is under case number 24-CI-00065, that Mrs. Combs was served by the Morgan County Sheriff’s Office, and that she filed a handwritten answer indicating that she is not represented by legal counsel. The sender asked Kentucky Farm Bureau to confirm whether they will or will not provide legal counsel for Mrs. Comb before proceeding any further. The Whaley Law Firm contact details accompany the signature, including the new email address: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com.

The email chain includes a forwarded message from Sarena Tuttle dated July 31, 2024, at approximately 2:43 PM (the original text shows “2:43?PM”), sent to Holly Highley with cc to Greg Whaley and Bryce Koon. In that message, Tuttle indicates she had left a voicemail regarding the above-referenced claim and that copies of the documents referenced in the voicemail may be of interest. She states that the Complaint filed against Mrs. Combs in Morgan County Circuit Court is attached, under case number 24-CI-00065. She notes that Mrs. Combs was served by the Morgan County Sheriff’s Office and filed a handwritten answer indicating she is not represented by legal counsel, and again asks whether Kentucky Farm Bureau will or will not be providing legal counsel for Mrs. Comb before proceeding any further. The message is signed with Sarena M. Tuttle’s contact information and reiterates the firm’s details.
episodes.author: Sarena Tuttle

episodes.natural_language:
Initial client contact on October 30, 2024, with Sarena regarding the Michael-Crader-MVA-5-19-2023 case for Michael Crader. The client left a voicemail stating they are checking the status.

Notes from the contact indicate that all litigation tasks were marked complete in August, but discovery was not complete, depositions had not been scheduled, and the mediation review was not complete. The uncompleted tasks include sending an update request to BK; only DC response to discovery requests has been received; there is no DC Disc Req PP Client; the client deposition is not scheduled; and the case is definitely not ready for mediation. We are awaiting BK update before calling the client back.

From: Bryce Koon [bryce@whaleylawfirm.com](mailto:bryce@whaleylawfirm.com)

Date: Thu Oct 31 2024 02:39:23 GMT-04:00

Good afternoon counsel,

Thank you for taking my call today. As discussed, we are working on my
client's discovery responses and should have them over to you shortly.

Prior to initiating the instant action, it was expressed that there was a
possible issue with other parties preventing disbursement of the minimum
policy limits. Do we have any updates on those other individuals and/or
their potential claims?

Any update appreciated.

Thank you,
*W. Bryce Koon, Esq.*
The Whaley Law Firm
712 Lyndon Lane
Louisville, KY 40222
Phone: (502) 365-5043
Fax: (502) 237-3207

*This electronic message is intended only for the named recipient. It may
contain attorney-client privileged or otherwise protected information. If

waiver of any privilege shall be applicable, and you are instructed that
you should not use the information contained herein or forward it to any
third person not intended to receive it. *
episodes.natural_language:
This note concerns the case Michael Crader v. Megan Combs in Morgan Circuit Court, Case 24-CI-00065, which is part of the Michael Crader motor vehicle accident (MVA) file dated May 19, 2023. The client is Michael Crader.

On October 31, 2024, at 2:39:23 a.m. (GMT-04:00), Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email titled to counsel regarding the Michael Crader v. Megan Combs matter. The email was sent from bryce@whaleylawfirm.com to johnellis@dehnerandellis.com, with Michael Crader MVA 5/19/2023 - Filevine Project Email Address (MichaelCraderMVAZ3893535@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com) included as a CC. The message began, “Good afternoon counsel,” and thanked the recipient for taking the call earlier that day. Koon stated that, as discussed, the firm is working on the client’s discovery responses and expects to provide them shortly.

Koon noted that prior to initiating the instant action there was a possible issue with other parties potentially preventing disbursement of the minimum policy limits. He asked whether there were any updates on those other individuals or their potential claims and requested any such update. The email concluded with the signature of *W. Bryce Koon, Esq.*, The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with phone number 502-365-5043 and fax number 502-237-3207. The message also included a standard attorney-client privilege disclaimer, stating that the electronic message is intended only for the named recipient, may contain privileged or protected information, and that if received in error the recipient should contact The Whaley Law Firm, acknowledge no waiver of privilege, and refrain from using or forwarding the information to anyone not intended to receive it.

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ Recvd Call from Client & Wife - Checking Status of things - Advised we are about to begin Deposition Scheduling - Location will need to be discussed - Client is in Mize, KY - DC is in Morehead, KY - Which is approximately 2.5 hours from Our office - Clients prefer Zoom if possible

Client also provided update that he is going to Troy Bowling Campus (VA Clinic) for Spinal Injections - last Appt 10.28.24 - Next Appt 05.14.25 - Every 6 Months until they stop working - Once they stop working he will be a Sx Candidate - Added to Provider Tab 
__Person Making Contact:__ Sarena
__Date & Time__: December 03 2024
episodes.natural_language:
Initial client contact on December 3, 2024, with Sarena regarding the Michael-Crader-MVA-5-19-2023 case for Michael Crader. The client and his wife called to check the status of matters and were advised that we are about to begin deposition scheduling, though the deposition location will need to be discussed. The client is in Mize, Kentucky, while DC is in Morehead, Kentucky, which is approximately 2.5 hours from our office. The clients prefer Zoom if possible.

The client also provided an update that he is going to Troy Bowling Campus (VA Clinic) for spinal injections. His last appointment was October 28, 2024, and the next appointment is May 14, 2025, with injections every six months until they stop working. Once they stop working, he will be a Sx Candidate. This update was added to the Provider Tab.

The Whaley Law Firm has requested Michael Crader’s signature on an attached document and asks him to follow the prompts to execute it.

On December 20, 2024, at 4:32 PM Eastern time, Michael Crader sent an email from his address michaelcrader67@gmail.com to Aaron Whaley at STuttle.wlf@gmail.com. In this message, he discusses Interrogatory number five. He explains that a man they had working part-time was called in to work on the day of the accident, and $300 was paid by KFB. He states that they lost wages because they had to hire someone to install a waterline, amounting to $10,800, which has not been reimbursed. He adds that his wife has not been able to go out to work since she has had to take on much of the farm work that he originally would have performed, resulting in additional lost wages. He questions why their taxes for the last five years are being requested, saying it doesn’t make sense and that he does not want them to know how much money they have, expressing a concern that he does not want them to come after them. The message ends with “Sent from my iPad.”

Earlier, on December 19, 2024, at approximately 2:46 PM, Aaron Whaley sent a document via DocuSign to Michael Crader for review and signing. The subject or heading indicates an envelope activation. The message reads: “Envelope Activation — Aaron Whaley sent you a document to review and sign.” The body of the message instructs Michael to review the attached Responses to the Defendant Comb’s Discovery Request, and if he is satisfied with the responses, to execute the attached verification page. He is instructed to click “Finish” so the document will re-route back automatically. The message provides contact information for questions: (502) 583-4022 Ext 104 or Bryce at Ext 114, and is signed by Sarena on behalf of The Whaley Law Firm.

The DocuSign email contains standard notices, including a warning not to share the email, the alternate signing method with the security code 568DE87F97444B5481CFA7117A3D32E67, and explanations about DocuSign’s secure, legally binding electronic signing process. It notes that if Michael needs to modify the document or has questions about its details, he should contact the sender directly. It also includes options for stopping future emails and troubleshooting signing issues, and states that the message was sent by Aaron Whaley, who is using the DocuSign Electronic Signature Service.

episodes.original_body:
Case: Michael-Crader-MVA-5-19-2023
Client: Michael Crader

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ Client Executed Resp to DC Disc Req Verification & Had questions: 

Aaron
Interrogatory number five
We had a guy working for us part-time and I had to call him in and to work the day of the accident. $300 was paid by kfb
We lost wages by having to hire out to have waterline put in $10,800. Not reimbursed.
My wife hasn’t been able to go out and work because now she has to do a lot of the work that I was supposed to be able to do on the farm so that is lost wages.

Taxes for the last 5 years ? Why do they need our taxes. That doesn’t make sense and don’t want them to know what money I have. I don’t want them to come after us, knowing them amount of money we have.

Replied to Client:
Good morning Michael,
While yes the things you listed are 'Special Damages', they do not necessarily fall under the 'Lost Wage' category. This particular question is directly related to your lost income, not additionally incurred expenses. As far as your Taxes, your Taxes are directly related to your income. As a self-employed individual/business owner, your Taxes are your statement of income to the government and are used to determine and verify your claim of 'Lost Wages', any diminished capacity to earn as well as any lost revenue from your farm. However, I will note your questions to Aaron & Bryce for further explanation if needed. 
__Person Making Contact:__ Sarena
__Date & Time__: December 23 2024
episodes.natural_language:
Case: Michael-Crader-MVA-5-19-2023. Client: Michael Crader.

Initial client contact in this motor vehicle accident matter occurred when Michael Crader executed his response to the discovery request verification and raised several questions for Interrogatory No. 5. In his notes, he wrote that they had a part-time worker whom they had to call in to work the day of the accident, and that $300 was paid by KFB. He stated that they lost wages because they had to hire someone to install a water line, a cost of $10,800, which has not been reimbursed. He also noted that his wife has not been able to go out to work because she now has to take on much of the farm work he was supposed to perform, resulting in additional lost wages. Regarding taxes, he asked, “Taxes for the last 5 years? Why do they need our taxes. That doesn’t make sense and don’t want them to know what money I have. I don’t want them to come after us, knowing them amount of money we have.”

Replied to client: “Good morning Michael, While yes the things you listed are 'Special Damages', they do not necessarily fall under the 'Lost Wage' category. This particular question is directly related to your lost income, not additionally incurred expenses. As far as your Taxes, your Taxes are directly related to your income. As a self-employed individual/business owner, your Taxes are your statement of income to the government and are used to determine and verify your claim of 'Lost Wages', any diminished capacity to earn as well as any lost revenue from your farm. However, I will note your questions to Aaron & Bryce for further explanation if needed.”

Person Making Contact: Sarena.
Date & Time: December 23, 2024.

It also provided links for new third-party billing requests to the VA’s Federal Medical Care Recovery Program (https://www.va.gov/ogc/collections.asp) and, for new CHAMPVA billing requests, to send requests to VHA Community Care at P.O. Box 469062 741/04, Denver, CO 80246-9062, with fax number 303/398-5116. It encouraged veterans to download their own health records at https://www.myhealth.va.gov/mhv-portal-web/web/myhealthevet/download-your-own-va-medical-records and pointed to VA resources at https://www.vets.gov/. The message ends with a notable instruction to verify fax numbers on the VA’s public website (https://www.va.gov/ogc/collections.asp) and mentions “VA Subrogation – Request VA Medical Bills.” It concludes with a garbled fragment: “Please note our fax numbers have chttps://www.va.gov/ogc/collections.asp.”

The communications are part of the file labeled Michael Crader MVA 5/19/2023, and involve correspondence between counsel W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, and John J. Ellis, Esq., of Dehner & Ellis, PLLC, with Michael Crader listed on the case copy as the plaintiff for the MVA claim dated 5/19/2023. The cc line for one message includes Michael Crader MVA 5/19/2023 - Filevine Project Email Address.

On Monday, December 30, 2024, at 10:47:37 GMT-05:00, Bryce Koon sent an email to counsel, attaching Plaintiff’s Discovery Responses along with the associated notice filed that day. He stated that the document production was available at a Dropbox link and provided the link: https://www.dropbox.com/scl/fo/7j7c3qnfg8p5qlc021ya9/ACHRPxamGiB1Pgz_nFzIDDw?rlkey=he36egaz7g28ef40v8bruzcs3&st=8cxa0ov3&dl=0. He asked that if there were any questions regarding the production, counsel should let him know. The message concluded with his signature, listing W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone 502-365-5043; fax 502-237-3207. The standard confidentiality and privilege disclaimer followed, noting that the electronic message is intended only for the named recipient, may contain attorney-client privileged or otherwise protected information, and that if received in error, the recipient should contact The Whaley Law Firm, that no waiver of privilege is applicable, and that the information should not be used or forwarded to anyone not intended to receive it.

The email thread also includes earlier communications. In a message dated November 11, 2024, at 3:09 PM (the exact time appears as 3:09?PM in the original formatting), John Ellis responded to Bryce Koon, apologizing for the delay and stating that he had reviewed his file and did not, at that time, have any information regarding other potential claims. Ellis asked Bryce to provide his client’s discovery responses at his earliest convenience. The November 11 reply was followed by a prior message from Bryce Koon dated October 31, 2024, in which he thanked counsel for taking his call and explained that they were working on the client’s discovery responses and expected to forward them shortly. In that October message, Bryce inquired about any updates on other individuals or potential claims, noting a prior discussion that there might be an issue with other parties preventing disbursement of the minimum policy limits and requesting any updates on those other individuals or claims.

The thread includes the standard attorney contact information and, at the end of the November 11 message, the signature block for John J. Ellis, Dehner & Ellis, PLLC, with office address listed as 206 East Main St., Morehead, KY 40351, and phone and fax numbers 606-783-1504 and 606-784-2744, respectively. The messages also carry the repeated disclaimer language common to electronic communications: the message is intended only for the named recipient, may contain privileged or protected information, and if received in error, the recipient should contact the sender and refrain from distributing the content.

Case: Michael-Crader-MVA-5-19-2023
Client: Michael Crader

@bryce3 Client Executed Verification Page - Notarized - Ready to go back to DC - Recvd Client Email Regarding Responses: 
Aaron 
Interrogatory number five
We had a guy working for us part-time and I had to call him in and to work the day of the accident. $300 was paid by kfb 
We lost wages by having to hire out to have waterline put in $10,800. Not reimbursed. 
My wife hasn’t been able to go out and work because now she has to do a lot of the work that I was supposed to be able to do on the farm so that is lost wages. 

Taxes for the last 5 years ? Why do they need our taxes. That doesn’t make sense and don’t want them to know what money I have. I don’t want them to come after us, knowing them amount of money we have.

Replied to Client:
Good morning Michael,
 While yes the things you listed are 'Special Damages', they do not necessarily fall under the 'Lost Wage' category. This particular question is directly related to your lost income, not additionally incurred expenses. As far as your Taxes, your Taxes are directly related to your income. As a self-employed individual/business owner, your Taxes are your statement of income to the government and are used to determine and verify your claim of 'Lost Wages', any diminished capacity to earn as well as any lost revenue from your farm. However, I will note your questions to Aaron & Bryce for further explanation if needed.
episodes.natural_language:
Case: Michael Crader – MVA, file dated May 19, 2023. Client: Michael Crader.

The client executed a Verification Page, which was notarized, and is ready to be returned to DC. He also sent an email regarding the responses, noting Aaron in relation to Interrogatory No. 5.

In response to Interrogatory No. 5, the client stated that we had a man working for us part-time whom we had to call in to work on the day of the accident, and $300 was paid by kfb. He also said we lost wages by having to hire out to have a waterline installed, totaling $10,800, which has not been reimbursed. Additionally, he explained that his wife hasn’t been able to go out and work because she now has to perform much of the farm work that he was supposed to be able to do, which constitutes lost wages.

The client also raised a privacy concern regarding taxes: “Taxes for the last 5 years? Why do they need our taxes. That doesn’t make sense and don’t want them to know what money I have. I don’t want them to come after us, knowing them amount of money we have.”

Replied to client: Good morning Michael, While yes the things you listed are 'Special Damages', they do not necessarily fall under the 'Lost Wage' category. This particular question is directly related to your lost income, not additionally incurred expenses. As far as your Taxes, your Taxes are directly related to your income. As a self-employed individual/business owner, your Taxes are your statement of income to the government and are used to determine and verify your claim of 'Lost Wages', any diminished capacity to earn as well as any lost revenue from your farm. However, I will note your questions to Aaron & Bryce for further explanation if needed.

Stevenson, Paralegal Specialist with the Department of Veterans Affairs, Office of General Counsel (Revenue Law Group), sent an email to Sarena Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm. In her message she thanked Sarena for the current status and reported that the VA’s claim for Michael Crader, tied to the date of injury of May 19, 2023 (DOI: 5/19/2023), remains at $86,505.91. Stevenson noted that if Sarena possesses the fax sent on April 18, 2024, the claim has not changed. She provided the ECFax delivery details for that April 18, 2024 fax: the fax was delivered successfully. The Job/Fax ID was 4b79b51e-4a15-4ba9-8bbe-87e0327b0de5, and the sender's ECFax account was Office of General Counsel. Earlier in the thread, on December 30, 2024, Sarena Tuttle had written to Stevenson regarding the same case. She stated that Mr. Crader’s claim was currently in litigation and that a settlement was not anticipated any time soon. She advised Stevenson to diary an approximate 180 days, explaining that the case was in the written discovery phase and would require completion of the oral discovery phase before any settlement discussions could begin. Tuttle also requested an updated itemized ledger detailing each provider and service billed on the lien for review of relatedness. Tuttle signed as: Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal & Workers' Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, with the firm’s Louisville, Kentucky address (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222). Her direct line was (502) 357-9971, her office line (502) 583-4022 ext. 104, and her email was Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with a note to “PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS.”

Earlier that same day, Stevenson had written for a status update on Michael Crader’s case (DOI: 5/19/2023). She reported that the VA’s claim remained $86,505.91 and urged that any questions be directed to her, noting that billing requests should not be faxed to the new intake fax lines. She provided her contact information again (IPhone: 317-361-6278; Fax: 202-495-5041; hours M-F 8:00 a.m. – 4:30 p.m.) and reminded the recipient to reference the GCLAWS number in correspondence. The message included the same standard privacy and confidentiality notices and the same links to VA resources, along with the admonition that fax numbers on the VA’s public website have changed and should be verified before sending requests to the correct fax number. The signature block listed her formal role, department, and case assignments (Lexington, Louisville, Mountain Home, New Orleans; Mass Litigation), and repeated the same contact details.

In addition to the above, the message thread contained general administrative notes: a reminder that for new third-party billing requests, information could be found on the VA’s website under the VA Federal Medical Care Recovery Program and instructions for requesting medical bills and records (collections.asp). For NEW CHAMPVA billing requests, the notice directed sending requests to VHA Community Care, P.O. Box 469062 741/04, Denver, CO 80246-9062, with Fax # 303-398-5116. It also pointed out resources for veterans to download their own health records (myhealth.va.gov) and other VA resources (vets.gov). The “HOW WAS OUR SERVICE TODAY?” section warned that VA fax numbers on the public site have changed and recommended double-checking the site to ensure requests are faxed to the correct numbers (collections.asp). The note reiterated that the VA Subrogation process involves requesting VA medical bills and that fax numbers have changed.

In summary, the file status shows the VA claim for Michael Crader related to the May 19, 2023 injury remains at $86,505.91 as of early 2025, with the April 18, 2024 fax having been delivered and containing twelve pages. The case is in litigation with no anticipated settlement in the near term, and the parties are in the process of discovery, with an expected diary of about 180 days before settlement discussions. The parties continue to exchange requests for documentation, including an itemized ledger of billed providers and services, and both sides are reminded to use the correct contact channels and up-to-date fax numbers when communicating.

Case: Michael-Crader-MVA-5-19-2023. Client: Michael Crader. Re: 596-C-20240108-14823/GCL #541090/Crader.

In a communication thread beginning on December 30, 2024, Louise M. Stevenson, Paralegal Specialist with the Department of Veterans Affairs Office of General Counsel (Revenue Law Group), requested a current status on Michael Crader’s case, noting the date of injury as 5/19/2023. She stated that the VA’s claim in Crader’s case remained $86,505.91 and advised that, for questions regarding this existing case, all inquiries should be directed to her rather than faxing billing requests to the NEW intake fax lines. She also provided her contact details and emphasized that this was not a new case.

That same day, Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, responded. She confirmed that Crader’s claim is currently in litigation and that the firm did not anticipate a settlement in the near term. She advised diarying approximately 180 days, explaining that the parties are in the written discovery phase and would need to complete the oral discovery phase before any settlement discussions could begin. She also requested, in the meantime, an updated itemized ledger reflecting each provider and service billed on the lien for review regarding relatedness. She signed with her Whaley Law Firm contact information and noted her new email address.

On December 30, 2024, at 10:03 a.m. (ET), Stevenson replied with a reiteration of the current status request: a current status on Crader’s case (DOI: 5/19/2023) and the reminder that the VA’s claim remains $86,505.91. She reiterated that questions should be directed to her and advised against faxing billing requests to the new intake fax lines, given that this is an existing case.

The thread includes additional corporate communications and standard VA service disclosures typical of Stevenson’s messages, including:
- references to the VA’s collections resources and relevant links;
- guidance on where to send new CHAMPVA and third-party billing requests;
- reminders that veterans can access and download their health records via the VA portals;
- a reminder that fax numbers on the VA public site have changed and should be verified before sending requests.

Later, on January 2, 2025, at 2:58 p.m. (ET), Stevenson again provided Crader’s case status. She stated that the VA’s claim regarding Crader (DOI: 5/19/2023) was still $86,505.91 and added that if the recipient possessed the fax sent on April 18, 2024, then the claim amount had not changed. She provided the EcFax status as Delivered Successfully and included the fax delivery details: Job/Fax ID 4b79b51e-4a15-4ba9-8bbe-87e0327b0de5, originating fax number 14809071910, destination fax number 15023649363, duration of 448 seconds, total pages 12, subject “Claim Asserted - ATTY - Crader,” with submission on 04/18/2024 12:51:07 EDT and delivery on 04/18/2024 13:00:39 EDT. Stevenson signed with her professional details and additional guidance about VA resources and contact practices for this case.

Shortly after, at 3:03 p.m. on January 2, 2025, Sarena Tuttle replied, thanking Stevenson for the update but noting that she did not see an itemized ledger in Crader’s file. She requested that the VA send over the itemized ledger, stating that its absence was a deficiency and that she would greatly appreciate receiving it. Her message concluded with her standard Whaley Law Firm contact details and her updated email address.

In summary, the essential facts remain: Michael Crader’s VA claim for this case (DOI 5/19/2023) is consistently reported as $86,505.91. The case is in litigation with an anticipated diary window of about 180 days for discovery phases before settlement discussions. An April 18, 2024 fax transmission related to the claim was delivered, containing 12 pages and a subject line indicating “Claim Asserted - ATTY - Crader.” The most recent communications include a request for an itemized ledger documenting providers and services billed on the lien, which has not yet been provided, and a confirmation of the current status from the VA.

episodes.natural_language:
The case is Michael Crader’s motor vehicle accident from May 19, 2023 (MVA 5-19-2023), identified as 596-C-20240108-14823/GCL #541090/Crader, with the client being Michael Crader. The matter involves the VA’s subrogation interests and medical bills related to Crader’s care.

In late December 2024, The Whaley Law Firm’s Sarena M. Tuttle notified Louise Stevenson, a Paralegal Specialist with the VA Office of General Counsel Revenue Law Group, that Crader’s claim was currently in litigation. She stated that settlement was not anticipated in the near term and requested that Crader’s team “diary out approximately 180 days” since the case was in written discovery and would need to conclude the oral discovery phase before any settlement discussions could begin. She further asked for an updated itemized ledger reflecting each provider and service billed on the lien for relatedness.

On January 2, 2025, Sarena followed up to confirm status. In a message sent at 3:04 PM (external), she thanked Louise for the update but noted that she did not see an itemized ledger in the file she had received and requested that it be sent over.

Earlier on January 2, 2025, at about 2:58 PM, Louise Stevenson had replied to Sarena. She stated that the VA’s claim regarding Michael Crader, DOI May 19, 2023, remained $86,505.91. She added that if the recipient possessed the fax sent on April 18, 2024, the claim amount would be the same as no changes had occurred. Stevenson provided the details of a transmitted fax: EC Fax status was “Delivered Successfully.” The fax had Job/Fax ID 4b79b51e-4a15-4ba9-8bbe-87e0327b0de5, originated from the ECFax account “Office of General Counsel,” with Originating Fax Number 14809071910 and Destination Fax Number 15023649363. The transmission lasted 448 seconds and consisted of 12 pages. The subject was “Claim Asserted - ATTY - Crader.” It was submitted on April 18, 2024 at 12:51:07 EDT and delivered at 13:00:39 EDT.

Stevenson’s signature followed, reiterating her role and contact details as a Paralegal Specialist with the VA Office of General Counsel, Revenue Law Group, including phone numbers and hours (Mon–Fri, 8:00 a.m.–4:30 p.m.), and her email address Louise.Stevenson@va.gov. She included standard cautions about using secured/encrypted mail for veteran PII, referencing the GCLAWS number associated with Crader’s case in subject lines and correspondence, and a confidentiality notice. She also provided links for new third-party billing (the VA Federal Medical Care Recovery Program) and Champ VA billing, and noted resources for veterans to access and download their own health records via myhealth.va.gov, as well as other VA resources.

In the body of the January 2, 2025 correspondence, Stevenson reminded recipients that the file to be sent would be password protected and that she would not include the password in the email itself or in the subject line. She instructed the recipient to use the password 596-C-20240108-14823 to open the file and explained that the ledger would contain multiple tabs at the bottom, with “X” marks indicating care a veteran received in the community, and that the separate tab would provide a further breakdown for the community care. She noted that the password would not be included in the subject line or body of the email, and advised that if the file was not received that day, the recipient should contact her the following day, as some attorneys’ computer systems block password-protected files. She emphasized that unless the recipient explicitly told them they did not receive the email, they would not know that the file had not been received.

Additionally, Stevenson’s January 2, 2025 message included standard “How Was Our Service Today?” language and a reminder that fax numbers on the VA’s public website have changed, directing readers to verify the correct fax numbers at the VA’s collections page. She closed with the usual notices about VA subrogation, the need to request VA medical bills, and the updated fax numbers.

Throughout these exchanges, the parties repeatedly referenced the case’s GCLAWS number and the need to address Crader’s lien and related medical bills. The Whaley Law Firm’s contact details were repeatedly provided (Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal & Workers’ Compensation Case Manager; Louisville, KY), and Stevenson’s communications consistently urged secure handling of PII and adherence to VA processes and contact protocols.

In summary, the Crader case remains in litigation with the latest stated claim amount of $86,505.91 as of January 2, 2025, and the parties are awaiting an itemized ledger detailing each provider and service billed on the lien for relatedness. A password-protected digitized ledger was being prepared for transmission, with explicit instructions on protecting PII and navigating the password and multi-tab format, along with follow-up steps if the file was not received.

Case: Michael-Crader-MVA-5-19-2023. Client: Michael Crader. This motor vehicle accident case involves Michael Crader and communications with The Whaley Law Firm in late 2024 and early 2025 regarding discovery responses, damages, and case status.

On February 6, 2025, Michael Crader sent an email to Sarena Tuttle (sarena@whaleylawfirm.com) with the subject line noting that The Whaley Law Firm had requested his signature and to follow the prompts to execute the attached. In the body, he wrote: “SARE a Tuttle,” and asked for an update on the case. He recalled that, the last time he spoke to someone at the office, they expected the case would be in deliberations in January, but it was February and he had heard nothing since the end of January. He closed by saying he looked forward to hearing back soon and signed, “Sincerely, Michael Crader.” The message was sent from his iPad.

Earlier correspondence in this chain began on December 23, 2024. In that message, Sarena Tuttle replied to Michael, explaining that while the items he listed were “Special Damages,” they do not necessarily fall under the “Lost Wage” category. She clarified that the issue at hand was directly related to his lost income, not incidental expenses. She noted that taxes are directly related to income and, as a self-employed individual and farm owner, tax information serves as a statement of income to the government and is used to determine and verify claims of “Lost Wages,” any diminished capacity to earn, and any lost revenue from his farm. She concluded by saying she would forward his questions to Aaron and Bryce for further explanation if needed, and she included her contact information and noted his new email address.

On December 20, 2024, Michael Crader sent another message (the time listed as 4:33 PM, with a “Sent from my iPad” closing). In this note, he addressed “Interrogatory number five” and described work-related losses tied to the accident: a part-time worker had to be called in on the day of the accident, with $300 paid by KFB; wages lost due to having to hire someone to install a waterline amounted to $10,800 and were not reimbursed. He also explained that his wife could not go out to work because she had to perform much of the farm work he would have done, thereby constituting additional lost wages. He questioned why the taxes for the last five years were needed, expressing concern about sharing tax information and a reluctance to reveal financial details due to fear of consequences. The message ended with “Sent from my iPad.”

On December 19, 2024, Aaron Whaley sent Michael a DocuSign notification. The body, as relayed by Sarena, asked Michael to review the attached Responses to the Defendant Comb’s Discovery Request and, if satisfied, to execute the attached verification page. It instructed him to click “Finish” so the document would re-route back automatically. It provided contact options for questions: (502) 583-4022, Ext 104, or Bryce, Ext 114, and signed by Sarena, The Whaley Law Firm. The accompanying DocuSign notice emphasized that the email contained a secure link and should not be shared, and included a note that the signing could be done via an alternate method at Docusign.com using the security code 568DE87F97444B5481CFA7117A3D32E67, along with standard information about DocuSign’s services, and the usual instructions to reach out to the sender with any questions.

The December 20, 2024 DocuSign-related message also included boilerplate notices. It stated that the message was sent by Aaron Whaley using the DocuSign Electronic Signature Service and included typical disclosures such as “Do Not Share This Email,” as well as sections detailing alternate signing methods and the security code referenced above. The content also reiterated the option to download the DocuSign app and directed the recipient to DocuSign’s support resources for signing assistance.

Across these exchanges, the working contact details for Sarena M. Tuttle are listed as Litigation Paralegal & Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, located at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222. Her direct line is (502) 357-9971, and her office line is (502) 583-4022, Ext 104. Her email is Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with a note indicating it is her new email address.

The email was sent to Michael Crader at michaelcrader67@gmail.com, with Bryce Koon (bryce@whaleylawfirm.com) and Aaron Whaley (agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com) copied, and the date/time shown was Thursday, February 6, 2025, at 11:13:26 AM Eastern Time.

Good morning Michael, the email began. It stated that the written discovery phase (the packets of questions) has been answered and returned on both sides just before the New Year. In their last case review with Bryce, the firm discussed attempting to settle your claim before proceeding with oral discovery, also known as depositions. A deposition is described as a session where you, Bryce, and the Defense sit down with a court reporter to verbally review the facts of the case. If the Defense is willing to discuss settlement, they will begin the negotiations process; if they are not willing, they will move forward with scheduling the depositions. Bryce will follow up with the Defense Counsel, and you will be updated as soon as there is additional information.

Sarena M. Tuttle signed off as the sender, reiterating her role and providing contact details, including the firm’s new email address.

Earlier correspondence is part of the same thread. On February 6, 2025, at around 10:54 AM, Michael Crader replied to Sarena, writing: “SARE a Tuttle, Just touching base and seeing where we are at on the case. Last I spoke to someone at the office they expected we would be in deliberations in January but it’s February and haven’t heard anything since end of January. Looking forward to hearing back from you soon.” The message was sent from his iPad.

Turning back to December 2024, on December 23, 2024, Sarena wrote to Michael: “Good morning Michael, While yes the things you listed are ‘Special Damages’, they do not necessarily fall under the ‘Lost Wage’ category. This particular question is directly related to your lost income, not additionally incurred expenses. As far as your Taxes, your Taxes are directly related to your income. As a self-employed individual/business owner, your Taxes are your statement of income to the government and are used to determine and verify your claim of ‘Lost Wages’, any diminished capacity to earn as well as any lost revenue from your farm. However, I will note your questions to Aaron & Bryce for further explanation if needed.” Sarena’s signature identified her as a Litigation Paralegal & Workers’ Compensation Case Manager, and again provided the firm’s address and contact numbers, along with the note that this was a new email address.

On December 20, 2024, at 4:33 PM, Michael Crader wrote to the firm regarding Interrogatory number five. He stated: “Aaron Interrogatory number five We had a guy working for us part-time and I had to call him in and to work the day of the accident. $300 was paid by kfb We lost wages by having to hire out to have waterline put in $10,800. Not reimbursed. My wife hasn’t been able to go out and work because now she has to do a lot of the work that I was supposed to be able to do on the farm so that is lost wages. Taxes for the last 5 years ? Why do they need our taxes. That doesn’t make sense and don’t want them to know what money I have. I don’t want them to come after us, knowing them amount of money we have.” This message was sent from his iPad.

On December 19, 2024, Aaron Whaley sent a DocuSign notification to Michael. The email stated: “Aaron Whaley sent you a document to review and sign. REVIEW DOCUMENT.” The message then directed Michael to review the attached Responses to the Defendant Comb's Discovery Request and, if satisfied with the responses, to execute the attached verification page. Michael was instructed to click “Finish” so the document would re-route back automatically, and to contact The Whaley Law Firm directly at (502) 583-4022 Ext 104 or Bryce at Ext 114 if he had any questions. The signature line read: “-Sarena, The Whaley Law Firm.” The email included a header indicating it was powered by DocuSign, with the standard security notices, including: “Do Not Share This Email,” a secure signing link, and an alternate signing method with a security code (568DE87F97444B5481CFA7117A3D32E67). It also shared the typical DocuSign boilerplate, explaining electronic signature speed and safety, and reminded Michael that this email contained a secure link to DocuSign and should not be shared. The message concluded with the line: “This message was sent to you by Aaron Whaley who is using the DocuSign Electronic Signature Service. If you would rather not receive email from this sender you may contact the sender with your request.”

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Michael-Crader-MVA-5-19-2023. Client: Michael Crader. The Whaley Law Firm, with Sarena M. Tuttle as Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager, has been handling communications for Michael Crader regarding his motor vehicle accident case and related settlement and discovery matters.

On December 19, 2024, Aaron Whaley of The Whaley Law Firm sent Michael Crader a DocuSign notification requesting that he review and sign the document titled “Responses to the Defendant Comb’s Discovery Request.” The email advised Michael to review the document and sign if he was satisfied with the responses, and provided a secure signing link and alternate signing method, including a security code. The message identified Aaron Whaley as the sender and stated that the signer should not share the email, link, or access code, and it described DocuSign as the platform used for electronic signing. The contact details included in the message were Aaron Whaley’s and Sarena Tuttle’s, with a note that the new email address is Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com.

Shortly thereafter, on December 20, 2024, Michael Crader wrote back to Sarena Tuttle, addressing Interrogatory Number Five. He explained that a part-time worker had been called in to work on the day of the accident, resulting in a payment of $300 by KFB. He stated that they lost wages due to having to hire out for a water line installation, amounting to $10,800, which had not been reimbursed. He added that his wife has not been able to go out to work because she had to take on much of the farm work he could no longer perform, thus constituting more lost wages. He also asked why the defense needed their taxes and expressed a desire not to reveal their financial information.

On December 23, 2024, Sarena Tuttle replied to Michael, clarifying the distinctions between “Special Damages” and “Lost Wages.” She explained that the question pertained to lost income and possibly diminished earning capacity, as taxes are tied to income and are used to verify a claimant’s lost wages and lost revenue from the farm for a self-employed business. She noted that she would relay Michael’s questions to Aaron and Bryce for further explanation if needed and provided her contact details again, including the new email address.

Earlier, on December 20, 2024, Michael had also sent messages through DocuSign and email regarding the discovery process. The exchanges included discussion of the responses to discovery and the status of the case as it related to the ongoing discovery phases.

Moving forward to February 6, 2025, the status of discovery and settlement discussions was discussed. At 10:54 AM, Michael Crader wrote to Sarena Tuttle, seeking an update on the case. He noted that he had been told they would be in deliberations in January, but it was now February, and he had not heard anything since the end of January; he asked to be updated. At 11:13 AM, Sarena Tuttle replied that the written discovery phase had been answered and returned on both sides just before the New Year. She explained that, in a case review with Bryce, they discussed attempting to settle the claim before proceeding with oral discovery (depositions). She described a deposition as an in-person session with a court reporter where the facts of the case are discussed, and said that if the defense was willing to discuss settlement, negotiations would begin; if not, the depositions would be scheduled. Bryce would follow up with Defense Counsel, and Michael would be updated as additional information became available. At 12:15 PM, Michael responded, “Ok sounds great! Thank you.” Later, at 1:47 PM, Michael sent another message: “Just touching base on my case from our last correspondents on 2/6/25. Can you please let me know what progress you all have made, whether settlement discussions have been ongoing, or if we are proceeding forward with depositions.” This message was sent from his iPad.

On March 17, 2025, the thread includes a direct outreach from Sarena Tuttle with the subject: “Re: The Whaley Law Firm has requested your signature. Follow the prompts to execute the attached.” In that message, Sarena informed Michael that Bryce and the Defense had been conversing about his claim and that Bryce had resubmitted their demand for policy limits roughly the previous week. She stated that once a response is received, they would reach out with an update, and she invited Michael to contact them with any further questions. The signature block for Sarena included her title as Litigation Paralegal & Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, the firm’s address (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222), direct line (D: 502-357-9971), main office line (O: 502-583-4022 ext 104), and email (Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com), noting that this is a new email address. The message was sent from Sarena, and it included the firm’s standard Docusign-related disclosures about signing documents electronically.

That same day, March 17, 2025, at about 1:47 PM, Michael Crader replied to Sarena, saying he was “Just touching base on my case from our last correspondents on 2/6/25” and asking for an update on whether settlement discussions had been ongoing or if depositions were to proceed. The exchange indicates ongoing activity around settlement negotiations, potential depositions, and the need to sign the attached document referenced in the March 17 email.

Case: Michael-Crader-MVA-5-19-2023
Client: Michael Crader

In this case, the most recent message is from Michael Crader to Sarena Tuttle dated March 17, 2025. The subject line indicates that The Whaley Law Firm has requested Michael’s signature and that he should follow the prompts to execute the attached document. In that email, Michael touches base on his case and references their last correspondence on February 6, 2025. He asks Sarena to update him on any progress, specifically whether settlement discussions have been ongoing or if the team plans to proceed with depositions. He thanks her for her time and says he looks forward to hearing from her soon. The message was sent from Michael Crader’s iPad.

Earlier, on February 6, 2025, there are two distinct exchanges. The first is a brief reply from Michael Crader at approximately 12:15 PM that reads, “OK sounds great! Thank you,” and is also sent from his iPad. Earlier that same day, at about 11:13 AM, Sarena M. Tuttle replied to Michael. In her message, Sarena explains that the written discovery phase—those packets of questions—has been answered and returned on both sides just before the New Year. She notes that in a recent case review with Bryce, they discussed attempting to settle Michael’s claim before proceeding with oral discovery, also known as depositions. She describes a deposition as a session where Michael, Bryce, and the defense sit with a court reporter to verbally go over the facts of the case. If the defense is willing to discuss settlement, negotiations will begin; if not, they will move forward with scheduling the depositions. Bryce will follow up with the defense counsel, and they will update Michael as soon as additional information is available. Sarena’s signature identifies her as Litigation Paralegal & Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, with the firm’s Louisville, Kentucky address and contact numbers, and notes a new email address.

On February 6, 2025, at about 10:54 AM, Michael Crader had written to Sarena to touch base and inquire about the case’s current status. He recalls that someone at the office had indicated they would be in deliberations in January, but that it is now February and he has heard nothing since the end of January. He asks to hear back soon and signs the message, “Sincerely, Michael Crader.” This message was also sent from his iPad.

The chronology back before February includes communications in December 2024. On December 23, 2024, at approximately 10:36 AM, Sarena wrote to Michael regarding alleged damages. She explains that while the items Michael listed are “Special Damages,” they do not necessarily fall under the “Lost Wage” category. She clarifies that the question concerns his lost income, not additional incurred expenses. Regarding taxes, she explains that as a self-employed individual and business owner, taxes are essentially a statement of income to the government and are used to determine and verify the claim of Lost Wages, any diminished capacity to earn, and any lost revenue from his farm. She adds that she would note Michael’s questions to Aaron and Bryce for further explanation if needed. The message includes Sarena’s professional signature, reiterating her role and contact details, along with a note to be aware of her new email address.

Earlier, on December 20, 2024, at 4:33 PM, Michael Crader sent a message to Aaron. In it, he discusses Interrogatory number five and provides concrete figures: a part-time worker hired to cover the day of the accident cost $300 paid by KFB; lost wages due to hiring someone to handle a waterline project totaling $10,800, which has not been reimbursed; his wife has been unable to work because she now must perform much of the farm work he was supposed to handle, resulting in further lost wages. He also questions why the defense needs their taxes, stating that it does not make sense and that he does not want them to know how much money they have, fearing potential risk if those amounts are disclosed. The message concludes with the standard “Sent from my iPad.”

The December 19, 2024 email thread shows that Aaron Whaley had sent Michael a document via Docusign for review and signature. The subject line indicates that Aaron provided the document for Michael to review and sign, and to execute the attached verification page. The email instructs Michael to click “Finish” so the document would re-route automatically back to the firm, and to contact the firm at (502) 583-4022 Ext 104 or Bryce at Ext 114 if any questions arise. The email is part of Docusign’s secure signing process, including a security code (568DE87F97444B5481CFA7117A3D32E67) and notes emphasizing that the signing process is secure and legally binding. The message also includes standard Docusign boilerplate and instructions about sharing and accessing documents, and it references the sender, Aaron Whaley, and the recipient’s address and contact details. The message closes with the usual administrative notes about Docusign support and access.

This case note concerns Michael Crader’s motor vehicle accident matter against Megan Combs, filed in Morgan Circuit Court under case number 24-CI-00065. The client is Michael Crader, and the matter is referenced in the file as Michael-Crader-MVA-5-19-2023. Communications referenced here occurred between counsel at The Whaley Law Firm and counsel at Dehner & Ellis, PLLC, with the Whaley firm handling the Crader matter. The email chain includes W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm (the sender in the exchanges) and John J. Ellis, Esq., of Dehner & Ellis, PLLC (the recipient), with the following recipients and copies: Sarena Tuttle was copied, and Michael Crader’s MVA filevine email address MichaelCraderMVAZ3893535@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com was included in the cc line. The notice on the emails states that the messages are intended only for the named recipient and may contain attorney‑client privileged information, with instructions to contact The Whaley Law Firm if received in error and to refrain from using or forwarding the information.

On March 5, 2025, after written discovery appeared to be complete, Bryce Koon sent a settlement demand to John Ellis, stating that the demand was for the policy limits of $25,000. He noted that Crader’s medical expenses exceed $100,000 and that his client’s liability position remained confident. Koon asked whether the carrier would tender the policy limits so the parties could avoid the costs and delay of depositions. He included his standard contact information for The Whaley Law Firm: 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone 502-365-5043; fax 502-237-3207.

In response, on March 6, 2025 at 4:07 PM, John Ellis wrote to Bryce Koon to confirm that his settlement offer was, with the exception of any PIP lien, inclusive of all liens—including any medical liens or a U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs lien—and that there would be entry of an Agreed Order of Dismissal with prejudice.

Shortly thereafter, on March 6, 2025 at 4:13 PM, Bryce Koon replied, “Yes, that is correct.” The message included the same privilege disclaimer as the prior correspondence.

Finally, on March 18, 2025 at 11:01:59 AM (Eastern Time), Bryce Koon sent a follow-up email to counsel, saying, “Good afternoon counsel, just wanted to circle back on this one. Any update appreciated.” The email, like the others, included the standard privilege notices and the signature block for The Whaley Law Firm, with Koon’s contact details reiterated.

The note also includes the signature blocks for the other involved firm: Dehner & Ellis, PLLC, located at 206 East Main St., Morehead, KY 40351; phone 606-783-1504; fax 606-784-2744; email johnellis@dehnerandellis.com. The content reflects ongoing settlement discussions surrounding the Crader v. Combs matter, including the requested policy-limit tender, the handling of PIP and other liens, and the potential for an Agreed Order of Dismissal with prejudice, all within the context of the Morgan Circuit Court case 24-CI-00065.

Case: Michael-Crader-MVA-5-19-2023. Client: Michael Crader. The following is a narrative record of email exchanges and DocuSign activity involving Michael Crader and The Whaley Law Firm regarding his motor-vehicle-accident claim, spanning December 2024 through March 2025, and including settlement discussions, discovery responses, and requests for signature.

On December 19, 2024, Aaron Whaley sent Michael Crader a document to review and sign via DocuSign. The message instructed Michael to review the attached Responses to the Defendant’s Discovery Request and, if satisfied with the responses, to execute the attached verification page. Michael was told to click "Finish" so the document would re-route automatically back to The Whaley Law Firm, and he was provided contact options for questions: (502) 583-4022 Ext 104 or Bryce at Ext 114. The email was sent under Aaron Whaley’s name and referenced Sarena Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm, with the signature line indicating Sarena’s address and contact details, including the note to “PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS.”

On December 20, 2024, Michael replied with specifics about Interrogatory Number Five: he described having had a part-time worker who was called in to work the day of the accident, noting that $300 was paid by KFB. He also stated that they lost wages due to having to hire someone to install a waterline, totaling $10,800, which had not been reimbursed. He added that his wife has been unable to work because she must take on more farm tasks, contributing to additional lost wages. He questioned why the defense would need their taxes and expressed concern about sharing financial information, saying he did not want them to know how much money they have.

On December 23, 2024, Sarena Tuttle responded by clarifying that the items listed by Michael as “Special Damages” do not necessarily fall under the “Lost Wage” category. She explained that the question related to lost income, not additional incurred expenses. She noted that taxes are related to income, and as a self-employed individual and farm business owner, taxes reflect income to the government and are used to determine and verify lost wages, diminished capacity to earn, and lost revenue from the farm. She offered to note Michael’s questions to Aaron and Bryce for further explanation if needed, and she closed with her standard contact details and the reminder of her new email address.

On December 23, 2024, Sarena’s message was followed by the earlier content from Sarena again, outlining her title and the firm’s contact information.

On February 6, 2025, at 10:54 AM, Michael Crader wrote to Sarena Tuttle: he was seeking an update and noting that, from what he had heard, the case was expected to go to deliberations in January, but it was now February and he had not heard anything since the end of January. He asked to hear back soon.

At 11:13 AM on February 6, 2025, Sarena replied: the written discovery phase (the packets of questions) had been answered and returned on both sides just before the New Year. In a case review with Bryce, they discussed attempting to settle the claim before proceeding with oral discovery, also known as depositions. She explained that a deposition would involve Michael, Bryce, and the Defense sitting with a court reporter to review the facts of the case. If the Defense was willing to discuss settlement, negotiations would begin; if not, they would move forward with scheduling the depositions. Bryce would follow up with Defense Counsel, and they would update Michael as soon as additional information was available. Her email signature included her title and The Whaley Law Firm’s contact information, along with the note to use the new email address.

Also on February 6, 2025, at 10:54 AM, Michael Crader had written again to Sarena starting with, “SARE a Tuttle,” and stating that he was checking in to see where the case stood. He mentioned that someone at the office had expected deliberations in January, but it was February and there had been no update since the end of January, and he asked to hear back soon.

Later on February 6, 2025, at 12:15 PM, Michael replied: “Ok sounds great! Thank you Michael Crader,” signaling agreement or acknowledgment of the prior information.

Also on February 6, 2025, at approximately 1:47 PM, Michael Crader sent another message: “Just touching base on my case from our last corespondents on 2/6/25. Can you please let me know what progress you all have made if settlement discussions have been ongoing or if we are proceeding forward with depositions. Thank you again for your time and looking forward to hearing from you soon.” This message was sent from his iPad.

On March 17, 2025, at about 1:47 PM, Michael Crader again wrote: “Sarena, Just touching base on my case from our last corespondents on 2/6/25. Can you please let me know what progress you all have made if settlement discussions have been ongoing or if we are proceeding forward with depositions.” He thanked her and again requested an update, sending from his iPad.

Shortly after, on March 17, 2025 at approximately 2:10 PM, Sarena Tuttle replied: “Good afternoon Michael, Bryce & the Defense have been conversing about your claim & Bryce resubmitted our Demand for Policy Limits roughly last week. As soon as we receive a response, we will reach out with an update. If you have any other questions, please do not hesitate to contact us.” Her message was signed with her name and title and included The Whaley Law Firm’s contact details and a note about the new email address.

On March 18, 2025, at 10:36 AM, Michael Crader responded: “Sarena, Wow, I would’ve thought they would’ve provided the policy limits as of now. Sounds good hope to hear from you soon.” He signed, “Sincerely, Michael Crader,” and the message was sent from his iPad.

This sequence reflects ongoing efforts to obtain policy-limit information, discuss settlement versus depositions, and obtain signed discovery-related documents, with the firm providing updates and clarifying the discovery and settlement process throughout the period.
