Case: Michael-Crader-MVA-5-19-2023. Client: Michael Crader. This matter is Michael Crader v. Megan Combs in Morgan Circuit Court, case number 24-CI-00065. The file references and correspondence pertain to the Michael Crader motor-vehicle accident matter, with the project labeled “Michael-Crader-MVA-5-19-2023.”

In a chain of emails between March 5 and March 18, 2025, counsel discussed settlement and discovery status. On March 5, 2025 at 10:55 a.m., W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, sent a message to John J. Ellis, Esq., of Dehner & Ellis, PLLC, noting that written discovery appeared to be complete and that, before proceeding with depositions and incurring further time and expense, he was demanding the policy limits of $25,000. He emphasized that his client’s medical expenses exceed $100,000 and that they were confident in their liability position, and he asked to know whether the carrier would tender the policy limits to avoid unnecessary expense and delay. The email stated these positions and was accompanied by the customary attorney-client privilege disclaimer.

On March 6, 2025, at 4:07 p.m., John Ellis replied, confirming that Bryce’s settlement offer was, with the exception of any PIP lien, inclusive of all liens—whether medical liens or a U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs lien—and that an Agreed Order of Dismissal with prejudice would accompany the settlement.

Shortly thereafter, at 4:13 p.m. on March 6, 2025, Bryce Koon replied, “Yes, that is correct,” indicating agreement with Ellis’s confirmation. That exchange also included the standard privilege and confidentiality disclaimer typically accompanying such emails.

On March 18, 2025, at 11:01:59 a.m., Bryce Koon sent another message to counsel, requesting an update on the matter. The email was sent from Bryce Koon at The Whaley Law Firm to John Ellis at Dehner & Ellis, with Sarena Tuttle cc’d and including a Filevine project address for Michael Crader’s MVA file (MichaelCraderMVAZ3893535@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com). The message, like the prior communications, included the firm’s usual privilege disclaimer.

The March 18 email also carried the sender’s contact information: W. Bryce Koon, Esq., The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone number (502) 365-5043; fax number (502) 237-3207. The prior messages featured the following contacts: John J. Ellis of Dehner & Ellis, PLLC, located at 206 East Main Street, Morehead, KY 40351; telephone 606-783-1504; fax 606-784-2744; email johnellis@dehnerandellis.com. The thread shows the ongoing settlement discussions, with the March 5 demand for the policy limits, the March 6 confirmation that liens would be treated as described, and the March 18 request for an update, all within the context of the Michael Crader v. Megan Combs case in Morgan Circuit Court.

In the motor-vehicle accident matter Michael Crader v. Megan Combs, Morgan Circuit Court, the file is labeled Michael-Crader-MVA-5-19-2023, with Michael Crader identified as the client. The communication thread centers on counsel for Michael Crader and for Megan Combs: W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, acting for Michael Crader (and Mary Crader), and John J. Ellis, Esq., of Dehner & Ellis, PLLC, representing Megan Combs. The July 11, 2025 email from Bryce Koon was addressed to John Ellis and copied to a Filevine Project email for Michael Crader; the message header lists The Whaley Law Firm’s Louisville, Kentucky contact information and the usual attorney-client confidentiality notices.

The substantive back-and-forth began with John Ellis’s March 26, 2025 reply. Ellis explained that there are five potential claims against his client, Megan Combs. He understood that Bryce Koon represents Mary Crader and Michael Crader, and he noted that there were three passengers in Ms. Combs’s car who also have possible claims. He stated that Megan Combs’s vehicle carries liability coverage of $25,000 per person/$50,000 per incident. Because of these multiple potential claimants, Ellis said he would need to obtain releases from all of them. He expressed hope that the matter could be worked out, but cautioned that it would take some time. He invited Bryce to call if he wanted to discuss further.

On May 8, 2025, Bryce Koon followed up by email with counsel, asking for any updates in this regard. He included his standard confidentiality notices and the Whaley Law Firm contact information in the signature.

Then, on July 11, 2025, Bryce sent another brief inquiry: “Counsel, Any update for me on this one?” The email again carried the Whaley Law Firm’s Louisville contact details and the same confidentiality disclaimer. The CC line for this message indicates it was sent to Michael Crader MVA 5/19/2023’s Filevine project email address, alongside the John Ellis correspondence.

In summary, the case involves five potential claims arising from Megan Combs’s motor-vehicle collision—two from Michael Crader and Mary Crader and three from the other occupants in Ms. Combs’s car. The only stated liability coverage for the Combs vehicle is $25,000 per person/$50,000 per incident, and Ellis indicated that releases from all potential claimants would be needed. The parties have engaged in a multi-step settlement discussion, acknowledging it may require time, and the chronology includes repeated follow-ups in March, May, and July of 2025.

Case: Michael-Crader-MVA-5-19-2023
Client: Michael Crader

FILE REORGANIZATION COMPLETE - Michael Crader MVA Case: Completed comprehensive 5-phase file reorganization using 8-bucket directory system. Phase 1: Generated inventory of 94 files with 53 scrambled .md files for content-only analysis (filenames randomized to eliminate bias). Phase 2: Parallel processing with 3 sub-agents analyzing 40-file chunks to prevent context exhaustion. Phase 3: Quality review achieved 98.44% accuracy (1.56% error rate - only 1 error: VitalChart invoice miscategorized as Medical Records instead of Expenses, corrected before execution). Phase 4: Successfully executed 68 operations (67 moves/renames, 1 deletion) with zero execution errors. Phase 5: Verified 100% naming convention compliance, all PDF+MD companions reunited, root directory cleaned. RESULTS: 150 files organized across 8 buckets - Medical Records (60 files across 16 providers with Medical Records/Bills/Requests subfolders: Air Methods Corporation, Morgan County Ambulance, UK Healthcare, University of Kentucky, Morehead Physical Therapy, etc.), Insurance (27 files: BI/Kentucky Farm Bureau, PIP/Erie Insurance, PIP/Everett Cash Mutual, PIP/Capstone, UIM folder), Litigation (28 files including complaint, answer, discovery requests/responses, 2 files flagged NEEDS REVIEW for illegible Certificate of Service dates), Client (7 files: voicemails, communications), Investigation (9 files: scene photos), Expenses (2 files: VitalChart records retrieval invoice $139 waived), Case Information (16 JSON system files). KEY CASE DETAILS CONFIRMED: Accident 5/19/2023 Morgan County KY, defendant Megan Combs, lawsuit filed 5/21/2024 Morgan Circuit 24-CI-00065, defense counsel John Ellis (Dehner & Ellis), discovery completed 8/29/2024, policy limits $25K KFB BI (claim #4863358), medical bills exceed $100K (Air Methods $82,859, UK Hospital $37,316, West Liberty PT $2,905, Morgan County EMS $1,331), VA lien $86,505.91 creates critical shortfall issue, client is veteran farmer. All files now follow standard naming convention YYYY-MM-DD - Michael Crader - {Category} - {Originator} - {Description}. Case ready for continued litigation and settlement negotiations. Complete reorganization documentation saved to Reports/ directory including quality review summary, reorganization map, and verification report.
episodes.natural_language:
Case: Michael-Crader-MVA-5-19-2023. Client: Michael Crader.

A complete file reorganization was completed for the Michael Crader MVA case, employing an eight-bucket directory system and a five-phase process. Phase 1 generated an inventory of 94 files, including 53 scrambled .md files used for content-only analysis with filenames randomized to eliminate bias. Phase 2 employed parallel processing with three sub-agents analyzing 40-file chunks to prevent context exhaustion. Phase 3 issued a quality review with 98.44% accuracy (a 1.56% error rate); the sole error involved a VitalChart invoice that had been miscategorized as Medical Records instead of Expenses, which was corrected before execution. Phase 4 executed 68 operations—67 moves/renames and 1 deletion—with zero execution errors. Phase 5 verified 100% naming convention compliance, ensured all PDF and MD companions were reunited, and cleaned the root directory.

Results: A total of 150 files were organized across eight buckets. Medical Records accounted for 60 files across 16 providers, with subfolders for Medical Records/Bills/Requests and providers such as Air Methods Corporation, Morgan County Ambulance, UK Healthcare, University of Kentucky, and Morehead Physical Therapy, among others. Insurance comprised 27 files, including BI/Kentucky Farm Bureau, PIP/Erie Insurance, PIP/Everett Cash Mutual, PIP/Capstone, and an UIM folder. Litigation included 28 files, encompassing the complaint, answer, discovery requests/responses, with two files flagged NEEDS REVIEW due to illegible Certificate of Service dates. Client contained 7 files including voicemails and communications. Investigation contained 9 files, consisting of scene photos. Expenses included 2 files, notably the VitalChart records retrieval invoice for $139 that was waived. Case Information included 16 JSON system files.

Key case details confirmed: The accident occurred on 5/19/2023 in Morgan County, Kentucky, involving defendant Megan Combs. The lawsuit was filed on 5/21/2024 in Morgan Circuit as 24-CI-00065. Defense counsel is John Ellis (Dehner & Ellis). Discovery was completed on 8/29/2024. Policy limits are $25,000 with Kentucky Farm Bureau/BI (claim number 4863358). Medical bills exceed $100,000, with the following breakdown: Air Methods $82,859; UK Hospital $37,316; West Liberty PT $2,905; Morgan County EMS $1,331. A VA lien of $86,505.91 creates a critical shortfall issue. The client is a veteran and a farmer. All files now follow the standard naming convention: YYYY-MM-DD - Michael Crader - {Category} - {Originator} - {Description}. The case is ready for continued litigation and settlement negotiations. Complete reorganization documentation has been saved to the Reports/ directory, including the quality review summary, the reorganization map, and the verification report.
